docs.snippet: Mary Marvin Breckinridge Patterson, a New York debutante, photojournalist and broadcaster from war-torn Europe, peripatetic diplomatic spouse and philanthropist, died on Dec. 11 at her home in Washington. She was 97.    Mrs. Patterson was born in New...
docs.lead_paragraph: Mary Marvin Breckinridge Patterson, a New York debutante, photojournalist and broadcaster from war-torn Europe, peripatetic diplomatic spouse and philanthropist, died on Dec. 11 at her home in Washington. She was 97. Mrs. Patterson was born in New York to John Cabell and Isabella Goodrich Breckinridge. Her grandfathers were Benjamin F. Goodrich, the inventor and industrialist, and John Cabell Breckinridge, a vice president, a presidential candidate in 1860 and secretary of war for the Confederacy.

headline.main: Mary Patterson, Philanthropist And Wartime Broadcaster, 97

docs.snippet: In Paris, the oenological event of the fall may not have been the 2002 harvest but rather the opening of Lavinia, which bills itself as the largest wine and spirits shop in Europe.     With more than 16,100 square feet -- almost 10 times the retail...
docs.lead_paragraph: In Paris, the oenological event of the fall may not have been the 2002 harvest but rather the opening of Lavinia, which bills itself as the largest wine and spirits shop in Europe. With more than 16,100 square feet -- almost 10 times the retail area of the Manhattan wine shop Sherry-Lehmann -- spread over three floors near the Place de la Madeleine, Lavinia stocks 3,000 different French wines, 2,000 from everywhere else and 1,000 types of brandies, whiskies and the like.
docs.abstract: Article on opening of Lavinia, 16,100-square-foot wine shop in Paris, which bills itself as largest wine and spirits shop in Europe; photos (M)

headline.main: Imagine: Paris Excited About a Wine Shop
